Convention and Visitors Bureau (CVB) works with area tourism and hospitality-related businesses, non-profit organizations, and event promoters, to represent the area to potential travelers, tour operators, travel agents, meeting planners, and the travel media. The CVB staff of marketing, sales, communication and administration professionals act in accordance with initiatives outlined by the Halifax Area Advertising Authority (HAAA). ADMINISTRATION Administration is responsible for the overall management and operations of the CVB as well as Finance and Human Resource services. Staff Lori Campbell Baker , APR, CDME, Executive Director Chuck Grimes , Director of Finance Steven Pike , HR/Finance DESTINATION SALES Working closely with meeting planners, tour and travel operators, and sports groups, the Group Sales Department helps to recruit and coordinate with area partners to provide services for group meetings, citywide conventions, trade shows, and sports competition events to the destination. The CVB is an active member of many industry professional associations and promotes the area's meeting facilities and hotels at industry events worldwide. Staff Brenda Redmon , Director of Sales Brandon Little , Senior Sales Manager, Sports Business Development Mara Robin , Corporate Sales Manager Shannon Echemendia , Sales Manager Karen DiGiacomo , Tour & Travel Sales Manager Rashanda Denson , Group Sales Coordinator Gabriela Amado , Convention Services and Events Coordinator MARKETING & DESIGN This division of the CVB handles advertising, marketing, tourism event funding, consumer promotions, visitor information services and business development. Staff Kay Galloway , TMP, Chief Marketing Officer Jennifer Sims , CHIA, CAHTA, Marketing Systems Manager Tangela Boyd , Digital Marketing Manager Connor Rand , Partner Liaison & Tourism Affairs Brian Bentley , PDM, Manager of Corporate Partnerships and Events Ashley Mesmer , Digital Content Creator COMMUNICATIONS This division of the CVB focuses on media relations, travel journalist press trips, editorial and online content, event calendar, brand and message consistency, community relations, speaker's bureau and crisis communications. Entertainment Venues Transportation Services Statement of Accessibility ADA Accessibility Feedback Form Partner Gateway Partner Resources Share Beaches The best way to stay up-to-date with everything beach-related is to download the new Volusia Beaches app, available for free on the Google Play and iTunes App stores. The new app provides real-time updates on the status of beach ramps and staffed lifeguard towers, as well as beach conditions, off-beach parking and more. Unplug, relax and rejuvenate with a visit to beautiful Daytona Beach. With an expansive shoreline 500 feet wide at low tide, you’ll have plenty of elbow room to embark on a new adventure, create new favorite memories and soak in the warm Florida sunshine. From its close proximity to dining and entertainment to the fun atmosphere, Daytona Beach is the ideal family escape. Satisfy your craving for salt air by grabbing a quick bite right on the oceanfront . Or, simply kick back and let the rest of the world melt away. With 23 miles of Atlantic shoreline, numerous coastal parks offering convenient parking, and on-beach parking in designated zones, the Daytona Beach area - Ormond Beach, Daytona Beach, Daytona Beach Shores and Ponce Inlet -  has some of the most accessible beaches in Florida. Start planning your beach escape today! Frequently Asked Questions Is Daytona Beach handicap accessible? Yes, Daytona Beach is handicap accessible. For beachgoers with special needs, accessible ramps and Surf Chairs are available at no charge. Visitors can navigate safely and comfortably in surf and soft sand. Learn More Are the beaches in Daytona Beach open? Yes, the beaches in Daytona Beach are open. Our 23 miles of white-sand beaches are open to pedestrians 24/7 with free access! Cars are permitted in designated areas of the beach from sunrise to sunset, tidal conditions permitting. Travelers with disabilities find our beaches highly accessible, too. Explore some of the Daytona Beach area's more accessible locations and available rental supplies: Learn More What are the times for low and high tide in Daytona Beach? To see daily Daytona Beach tide information, check out Volusia.org for more details. Learn More Where can I park when I visit the beaches in Daytona Beach? With 23 miles of Atlantic shoreline, numerous coastal parks offering convenient parking, and on-beach parking in designated zones, the Daytona Beach area - Ormond Beach, Daytona Beach, Daytona Beach Shores and Ponce Inlet -  has some of the most accessible beaches in Florida. Learn More Live Web Cam Driving on the Beach Lifeguards Guidelines & Safety Public Parking Sea Turtles Beach Accessibility Pet Friendly Sponsored Sponsored Sponsored Sponsored Sponsored Sponsored Beach App - download the free Volusia Beaches app, provided by Volusia County Beach Safety, for real-time updates on the status of vehicle access ramps, beach conditions, beach park locator, ADA access and more. Download the Beach Navigator app here! Questions? While at the beach, feel free to contact one of our friendly Volusia County Beach Patrol officials for assistance. Please contact them at beachsafety@volusia.org and 386-239-7873 or contact us . We're here to help! OUR TEAM - Sunrise Company Sunrise Company OUR STORY OUR PLACES OUR TEAM OUR GALLERY CONTACT Menu OUR TEAM It takes an extraordinary team to bring the Sunrise Company communities to life. Founder and CEO William Bone has created a company that reflects his personal integrity and devotion to excellence. Under the leadership of the senior management team that averages 15 years with Sunrise Company, each team member is mentored to achieve personal and professional success. This is a place where diversity, imagination curiosity, and creativity are celebrated and a passion to excel and the desire to exceed expectations are evident in every person you meet. Fitness trainers, golf professionals, groundskeepers… pastry chefs. An attitude of enthusiasm, reliability and accountability. A place where the can do spirit is legendary. EXECUTIVE TEAM William Bone Founder and Chairman of the Board RANDALL BONE CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER Phillip K. Smith President Julie Bloom chief operating officer Dirk Gosda President, Southwest/Mountain Region JAVIER ESTRADA corporate controller Teddy farrell project manager luke gosda Senior Development Manager Email Us Directly info@sunriseco.com Call Us Directly 760-772-7227 Communities Andalusia Country Club Toscana Country Club Dancing Bear Aspen Employment Information Email Press Inquiries Email Copyright © 2023 Sunrise Company. All rights reserved. William Bone William Bone founded Sunrise Company in 1963 and is the Founder and Chairman of the Board of Sunrise Company. He is a nationally recognized expert in resort residential, hotel and recreation development having developed 13 country club communities, built over 20 golf courses, constructed more than 16,000 homes, built two resort hotels and developed numerous office buildings, shopping centers apartments and commercial hotels. Mr. Bone is frequently sought as a speaker on how to successfully design, develop and market these types of real estate projects. Born in Bakersfield, California, Mr. Bone received a B.A. in economics from Stanford University in 1963 and an M.B.A. with Distinction from The Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration in 1965. In 2003, Mr. Bone received the “Legends” Award from the National Association of Home Builders. In 1992 he was inducted into the California Building Industry Association Hall of Fame and also received the College of the Desert’s Alumni Association Hall of Fame award for community leadership. In June 1991, Mr. Bone was honored by the Desert Area, Riverside County Chapter of the Building Industry Association for his extraordinary contribution to post-secondary educational opportunities for the Coachella Valley residents. In addition to being selected 1991 Citizen of the Year by the Boy Scouts, Mr. Bone was awarded the Palm Springs Life Magazine’s Builder of the Decade in 1988. Randall Bone As Chief Executive Officer of Sunrise Company, Randall Bone brings more than 30 years of hands on experience in the development of more than $3 billion dollars in U.S. and international real estate development projects including highly successful residential communities, commercial and multifamily development. Starting his career in construction, Mr. Bone has moved through the critical path of project management, finance and new project start ups, building extensive experience in each aspect of the project development cycle and providing hands-on, detail oriented leadership and an ongoing commitment to the “Evolution of Excellence” which is responsible for the success of Sunrise’s distinctive, award winning developments. Mr. Bone is a former Trustee of the Urban Land Institute and a past member of ULI Board of Directors and Executive Committee. Mr. Bone is a past Chairman of the Recreational Development Council. Mr. Bone graduated Cum Laude from the University of California at Los Angeles with dual B.A. degrees in Economics and Philosophy, with departmental honors. Mr. Bone later received his M.B.A. with High Distinction as a Baker Scholar from The Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration. Phillip K. Smith, Jr. Phillip K. Smith, Jr., is the President of Sunrise Company. Mr. Smith serves as a member of the Company’s senior management team and provides direction on legal affairs, risk management, community development issues and other aspects of the business. Before joining Sunrise Company in 1980, Mr. Smith was a partner in the Los Angeles law firm of Greenberg, Glusker, Fields, Claman & Machtinger where he specialized in the legal aspects of real estate development and was a member of the Management Committee. Mr. Smith is a member of the Urban Land Institute and board member and president of the Desert Valleys Builders Association. He is a Trustee of the Family YMCA of the Desert, a Director of the Coachella Valley Economic Partnership, Indian Wells Town Hall and The Living Desert. He is a former board member of the Palm Valley School. Mr. Smith received a B.A. in International Relations from the University of California at Los Angeles and a J.D. from Stanford University School of Law. Julie Bloom Julie Bloom is the Chief Operating Officer for Sunrise Company and is responsible for the Coachella Valley Division in the Palm Springs desert resort area of Southern California, guiding the company’s real estate, construction and country club activities. Her experience spans many different markets, including primary home, luxury country club, resort and active adult. She was integral in the launch of Toscana Country Club and the successful relaunch of Andalusia Country Club after Sunrise acquired the community in 2018. Mrs. Bloom is also a key member of the strategic acquisitions team for Sunrise Company and serves as a member of the Company’s senior management team and provides guidance on strategic vision, corporate communications, technology, market and consumer research, investor relations and data analytics. She previously served as the company’s Senior Vice President of Operations, Vice President of Marketing and Las Vegas Regional Marketing Manager. Mrs. Bloom is a graduate of Northern Illinois University and Clemson University, where she received a Masters degree. She is a California licensed real estate broker. Dirk Gosda Dirk Gosda is the President of Sunrise Company’s Southwest/Mountain Region. In addition to being responsible for overall operations of his region, Mr. Gosda is also responsible for the acquisition of projects for Sunrise Company. In his 23 years with Sunrise, Mr. Gosda has served as the President of the Las Vegas, Houston and Colorado Divisions of Sunrise Company and while President Mr. Gosda has lead the acquisitions team for Sunrise Company. Mr. Gosda also served as President of Brookfield Residential’s Texas operations from 2014 to 2019, launching Kissing Tree, a 3,000 home Active Adult Community and Easton Park, a 10,000 home master planned community in Austin. In addition, during his tenure at Brookfield he started Brookfield’s homebuilding operations and grew home sales to over 500 homes a year. During his career Mr. Gosda has developed over 8,000 acres, the design, construction and sale of over 6,000 homes, 2,500 apartments and construction and operation of eight golf courses. Mr. Gosda has served in many civic, charitable and political capacities including Los Angeles County Parks and Recreation Commissioner, served on the Board of Trustees for the Castaic Union School District and a Board Member of HomeAid Austin. In addition, he has served on numerous community associations, including the Austonian Condominium Association in Austin, Texas. Gosda received a B.A. in Accounting from the University of Houston and was a Certified Public Accountant. Javier Estrada With a career spanning 20
years, Javier Estrada has gained a wealth of experience in auditing and
financial reporting. His professional journey has taken him through three
distinct industries: public accounting, corporate automotive and government. He
has prepared consolidated financial statements and budgets for government and
private sectors and led numerous internal and external auditing projects
throughout his career. He has served in leadership roles, including divisional
Treasurer for the California Municipal Revenue and Tax Association. He is a graduate of the University of Southern California and has an MBA with
an emphasis in Accounting from California State University, San Bernardino. He
is a Certified Public Accountant and holds a certification in government
financial management. Teddy Farrell Teddy Farrell is a Project Manager at Sunrise Company and is responsible for analytics, modeling, due diligence, sourcing capital and structuring deals on the Sunrise acquisitions team. Mr. Farrell has been a key team member in more than $350 million in strategic acquisitions by Sunrise Company and its affiliates since 2007. Such acquisitions included large land development projects, Active Adult projects, distressed debt, apartment buildings, commercial centers and resort opportunities. He managed the acquisition, development and sellout of Dancing Bear Aspen and was integral in the acquisition and relaunch of Andalusia Country Club. Mr. Farrell is a member of the ULI Recreational Development Council, and serves as an Executive Board Member of the Trashmasters International Charity and Executive Board Member of the Aspen Youth Center. Mr. Farrell graduated Cum Laude from the University of Vermont with a B.S. in Business Administration and Finance. Luke Gosda Prior to joining Sunrise Company, Luke served in various roles in the residential real estate sector, including multifamily construction as well as single family homebuilding and land development. As a Senior Development Manager, Mr. Gosda brings focus, passion, and excellence to land development. Luke oversees three active Master Planned Communities in Central Texas approved for over 17,000 lots, homes, single-family, multi-family, and commercial uses. With each MPC currently in various stages of the community life-cycle, he manages the assets from land acquisition through permitting, construction, and sale to various end users and builder-partners, including Brookfield’s internal housing operation. Starting his career in public accounting in Silicon Valley as a CPA, Mr. Gosda has developed the skills and expertise surrounding financial accounting through various industries and business models, ultimately landing on a passion in forging places and community. Through years of project management, Luke has developed an acute attention to detail and an analytical mindset to effectively bring vision to reality. His zeal to learn and his strategic acuity permeate his leadership style. Primary Menu OUR STORY OUR PLACES OUR TEAM OUR GALLERY CONTACT

If you have any questions, please view our frequently asked questions (FAQ) below or you can contact us at one of the contact methods below. Our phone lines are currently down. Please contact us via Facebook Messenger or email: guestservices@sunrise.ski × Season Passes Upcoming Events Employment COVID-19 Safety Address & Directions Mailing Address PO Box 3070 Pinetop, AZ 85935 Physical Address 200 Highway 273 Greer, Arizona 85927 Getting to Sunrise Frequently Asked Questions General Info Mountain & Lifts Zip Line Rentals & Lockers Lessons Ski Biking First Timers Tubing & Sledding Do you have lockers? SWGMedia 2023-12-14T17:55:59-07:00 Do you have lockers? We do! Both day lockers and season lockers will be available this season: Day lockers are available for rent via kiosk on the first floor of the Sunrise Day Lodge or in the Crown Dancer Café and Grill. Day lockers are $8 per day for small and $12 per day for large lockers. Season lockers have limited availability and come with an assigned parking space this season. Please inquire with Guest Services for more information. Can I bring my own Ski Bike? SWGMedia 2022-11-27T08:02:56-07:00 Can I bring my own Ski Bike? Yes, you can ride your own ski bike if you meet the following two requirements: Ski bike riders visiting Sunrise require a safety certification by the ski bike staff prior to loading the lifts, regardless of their experience or personal equipment to ensure the safety of themselves and other visitors. Your bike has to be inspected by the ski bike staff to ensure it has the proper safety features. Ski Bikes are only allowed on Cyclone Circle and Apache Peak. Do you offer Ski Bike lessons? SWGMedia 2022-11-27T08:04:06-07:00 Do you offer Ski Bike lessons? Yes! We have Ski Biking lessons on Saturdays and Sundays at Cyclone Base once that mountain opens this season. Ski Bike lessons are available for ages 13+. More information about ski bike lessons is available below: Ski Bike Lessons What is Ski Biking? SWGMedia 2022-11-27T08:04:54-07:00 What is Ski Biking? Ski Biking (also known as Skibobbing) is a bicycle-like frame with skis instead of wheels. Ski Bike rentals and lessons are available at the base of Cyclone Circle. First-time ski bike riders at Sunrise Park Resort require a safety certification by the ski bike staff prior to loading the lifts, regardless of their experience or personal equipment to ensure the safety of themselves and other visitors. Are there additional requirements for riding the zip line? SWGMedia 2024-07-15T10:53:42-07:00 Are there additional requirements for riding the zip line? You must be at least 10 years of age. Permittable weight range: 70lbs to 230lbs. Must wear close-toed shoes that can be secured to your feet. No sandals, flip-flops, or crocs. No hats or other lose objects that can fly off during your zip line ride. Guests must not be over 3 months pregnant. What should I wear while zip lining? SWGMedia 2021-05-24T12:51:49-07:00 What should I wear while zip lining? Guests must wear closed-toe shoes, flat heels. Long hair must be tied back. Remove all jewelry or scarves. Remove extra layers of clothing What are the weight restrictions on the zip line? SWGMedia 2021-05-24T13:11:00-07:00 What are the weight restrictions on the zip line? Guests must weigh between 70-230 lbs to ride the zip line Is tubing and sledding offered? SWGMedia 2023-03-17T19:58:11-07:00 Is tubing and sledding offered? The Tubing Hill is back! Sunrise does not offer on-site sledding, but we have a tubing hill at the base of Sunrise mountain with fun for everyone 6 and up. Hours and tickets are available at the link below: Tubing What do you do with moguls in the summer? Are they manmade? SWGMedia 2020-12-29T22:40:16-07:00 What do you do with moguls in the summer? Are they manmade? Moguls are formed by skiers on virtually all ski trails that are not mechanically flattened with grooming equipment. They organize spontaneously as skiers move along a ski run, kicking up snow behind them as they turn. The kicked-up snow forms into piles, which eventually turn into moguls. Check out this time lapse video of how moguls actually move uphill over time! Does it have to be less than 32 degrees for the roads to ice? SWGMedia 2020-12-29T22:39:29-07:00 Does it have to be less than 32 degrees for the roads to ice? No. Temperature readings below 36°F should alert you to the possibility of road icing. Read more about Icy Road Conditions. I’ve never been skiing / snowboarding. What should I wear? SWGMedia 2021-11-03T15:28:31-07:00 I’ve never been skiing / snowboarding. What should I wear? Because of changing weather conditions, and depending upon your level of activity, layering clothes is recommended. Be aware that MORE is not necessarily better, and in many cases wearing too much clothing can be physically limiting. Follow these guidelines: Start with a comfortable, breatheable base layer like thermal underwear, merino wool, etc. Wear only one thin pair of socks (merino wool is optimal since it wicks moisture away from your feet and is very warm). This is important! Wearing thick, bulky socks or multiple pairs of socks restricts circulation, creates pressure points and does not allow your feet to breathe. If it is especially cold, you can add a sweater or fleece over your base layer. Wear something that is easy to shed if the sun comes out and warms things up. Waterproof outerwear (pants & jackets), especially for beginners who tend to fall a lot. Jeans and sweatpants get wet quickly in snow and will ice up. Skiing or snowboarding is a lot more fun when you are warm and dry! Waterproof gloves or mittens will keep your fingers toasty warm. Knit gloves will get wet after falling only a couple of times, not so fun. Be sure your children have waterproof gloves/mittens as well. Goggles or UV protective sunglasses/eyewear. Snow is a natural reflector of sunlight. Without UV protection your eyes (cornea) can get a “sunburn” which feels scratchy and uncomfortable. Like skin, repeated cornea burns can cause long term damage. So take care of your eyes – wear sunglasses! Don’t forget a warm beanie, hat or helmet to keep your head warm! There’s a lot to be said about having a warm head when it’s snowing outside, so be prepared and bring your helmet, hat or beanie! Do you offer discounts for groups? SWGMedia 2022-12-14T19:24:51-07:00 Do you offer discounts for groups? Yes! Please fill out the form on the page below to request a quote for your group event at Sunrise: Group Sales How old does my child have to be for ski/snowboard lessons? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:04:27-07:00 How old does my child have to be for ski/snowboard lessons? We offer group lessons or private lessons for children 7 years and up. Private lessons are available for ages 4 years and up. Ski Bike lessons are available for ages 13+. More information about lessons is available below: Lessons How do I book lessons? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:05:47-07:00 How do I book lessons? You can book lessons at the link below. We have limited lessons daily and prices increase if you book less than 72 hours in advance, so be sure to book in advance for the best deal. Lessons What is the Responsibility Code? SWGMedia 2020-12-29T22:40:29-07:00 What is the Responsibility Code? Skiing and snowboarding can be enjoyed in many ways. At areas, you may see people using alpine skis, snowboards, telemark skis, cross country skis, and other specialized equipment, such as that used by people with disabilities. Regardless of how you decide to enjoy the slopes, always show courtesy to others and be aware that there are elements of risk in skiing that common sense and personal awareness can help reduce. Observe the code listed below, and share with other skiers and riders the responsibility for a great skiing experience. Always stay in control, and be able to stop or avoid other people or objects. People ahead of you have the right of way. It is your responsibility to avoid them. You must not stop where you obstruct a trail, or are not visible from above. Whenever starting downhill or merging into a trail, look uphill and yield to others. Always use devices to help prevent runaway equipment. Observe all posted signs and warnings. Keep off closed trails and out of closed areas. Prior to using any lift, you must have the knowledge and ability to load, ride and unload safely. Know the code. It’s your responsibility. *Note: This is a partial list. Be safety conscious. The National Ski Areas Association has put together a “Know the Code” video; view it below. My spouse has never been skiing/snowboarding. Should I teach them? SWGMedia 2020-12-29T22:41:34-07:00 My spouse has never been skiing/snowboarding. Should I teach them? Many couples, families and friends prefer to leave the lessons to the pros. Our winter sports staff receives continuous training and certifications, keeping up with the most current equipment and PSAI | AASI lesson standards. There is a progression to teaching a new student on the snow that builds gradually upon the most basic skills. As students grasp the concepts needed to master the beginner hill, many other factors come into play that are determined by movement analysis – subtleties your pro instructor has been trained to detect that most novice skiers and snowboarders are unaware of. And finally, our pros take the safety of our guests seriously, integrating the Skier | Snowboarder Responsibility Code into the lesson. Safety + Fun = Learning! What are your hours? SWGMedia 2025-02-16T22:22:07-07:00 What are your hours? Sunrise is now open daily for the 2023/24 ski season. Our hours on all operating days are 9am to 4pm. Night skiing is runs from 4:30pm to 8:00pm and is offered Dec. 26-31, Jan. 18-19, and Feb. 15-16. You can arrive early to pick up your passes and rentals. Are the rental shops open? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:07:28-07:00 Are the rental shops open? Yes! The ski and snowboard rental shop at Sunrise base is open during resort hours. The rental shop at Cyclone base will offer Ski Bike rentals on Saturday and Sunday soon as that side of the mountains open. You can find more information and book rentals at the link below: Rentals Do you have ski and snowboard rentals? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:16:35-07:00 Do you have ski and snowboard rentals? Yes! Sunrise has partnered with Rossignol for rental skis and snowboards. Skis and snowboards are available for nearly all ages and sizes New this season – Premium Rossignol and Dynastar Demo skis. Try out these latest high-end skis on the snow with an opportunity to purchase them to call your own. Rentals Will Apache Peak and Cyclone Circle be open? SWGMedia 2023-12-14T17:53:15-07:00 Will Apache Peak and Cyclone Circle be open? Yes! (as snow levels allow) Apache peak will be open this season with Geronimo (Lift 5) servicing the mountain. Cyclone Circle will be open with access via the Cyclone Cord on Denny’s Way on Thursdays through Sundays as snow levels allow. See the snow report below for the most current lift and trail status: Snow Report Do you have night skiing? SWGMedia 2023-08-29T01:08:22-07:00 Do you have night skiing? Yes, night skiing is available from 4:30 pm to 8:00 pm on select nights. The scheduled night skiing dates for the 2023/24 season are: December 26 – December 31 MLK Weekend: January 13-14 President’s Day: February 17-18 We also have fireworks and a torch light parade scheduled for New Years Eve (Dec. 31), starting around 8:15pm. Is Eagle’s Nest open? SWGMedia 2022-12-14T19:20:21-07:00 Is Eagle’s Nest open? Eagle’s Nest (café at the top of Sunrise Mountain) is open throughout the season for dining. For hours and menus, visit the link below: Hours and Menus Do you have a conveyor belt for beginners? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:21:02-07:00 Do you have a conveyor belt for beginners? Yes, we have a conveyor at the learning hill for the Mountain Learning Center. We also have the small, two-person lift on the Bunny Hill for beginners. What’s up with Cyclone? SWGMedia 2023-12-14T17:53:59-07:00 What’s up with Cyclone? Cyclone Circle will be open for the 2023/24 season! The new Cyclone Cord, a “Swiss Cord” style surface lift, was installed last season. Cyclone access will be available Thursday – Sunday as snow levels allow. The old Cyclone chairlift (Lift VI) was deemed unrepairable a few years ago and the lift cable has been removed. Do you offer childcare? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T13:04:57-07:00 Do you offer childcare? No, we will not be offering childcare this season. Camp Sunrise will offer Youth group ski lessons for ages 7-12 this season. More information about those lessons is available below: Camp Sunrise Lessons Are drones allowed at Sunrise? SWGMedia 2021-05-23T19:08:45-07:00 Are drones allowed at Sunrise? No. For the safety of you and other skiers, unauthorized use of drones and all other small unmanned aerial systems (UAS) at SPR is strictly prohibited. Any drone use must be authorized by the Sunrise Park Resort management prior to use. Do you have a lost and found? SWGMedia 2021-02-02T14:47:36-07:00 Do you have a lost and found? Yes, please call 928.735.7669 Ext. 2301 Can I bring my dog? SWGMedia 2021-05-24T12:44:58-07:00 Can I bring my dog? Sunrise is pet friendly as long as your dog stays on leash in the base area. We only ask that you please pick up after your dog. Is there a restaurant at Sunrise? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:27:33-07:00 Is there a restaurant at Sunrise? Yes! There are four lodges, two cafés, and the Sunrise Pub for dining around the resort. Lodges include the Sunrise Day Lodge, Cyclone Day Lodge, and Apache Peak Lodge, and Midway Café (Sunrise Midway). Cafés include Eagle’s Nest (Sunrise Peak) and the Crown Dancer Café and Grill (old rental building at Sunrise Base). Dining menus and hours are available below: Hours and Menus Can I bring a grill or propane stove to cook my own food? SWGMedia 2021-05-24T12:46:15-07:00 Can I bring a grill or propane stove to cook my own food? No. Grills and propane stoves are not permitted. Can I bring my own food and beverages? SWGMedia 2022-11-28T09:28:21-07:00 Can I bring my own food and beverages? You may picnic on the outside decks, however, no outside food or beverages inside the lodges or Crown Dancer Café. No outside alcohol or coolers allowed on property at any time. Information and menus of our on-site dining can be found at the link below: Dining at Sunrise Phone & Email Directory Our phone lines are currently down. Please contact us via email or Facebook Messenger below: × Phone (928) 735-7669 Email guestservices@sunrise.ski FB Messenger m.me/SunriseSkiAZ Full Extension Directory Ski Patrol Emergency Line 928-735-7124 Contact Us Media and PR Employment Getting to Sunrise 200 Highway 273 Greer, Arizona 85927 Partners Owned and operated by the White Mountain Apache Tribe Subscribe Get the latest news, deals, and updates Partners Contact Us Media and PR Employment Getting to Sunrise 200 Highway 273 Greer, Arizona 85927 Owned and operated by the White Mountain Apache Tribe Subscribe Get the latest news, deals, and updates Partners Contact Us Media and PR Employment Getting to Sunrise 200 Highway 273 Greer, Arizona 85927 Subscribe Get the latest news, deals, and updates Owned and operated by the White Mountain Apache Tribe Copyright © 2020-2025 Sunrise Park Resort All Rights Reserved | Terms of Use | Privacy Policy Website Design and Marketing by SWG Media Page load link Go to Top

Convention and Visitors Bureau (CVB) has a number of advisory committees. Committee members are appointed by the Halifax Area Advertising Board. Committee Meeting Dates To learn more about the CVB Advisory Committees please review the list below. To apply please review the Guidelines and complete an Application . Completed applications should be submitted to Jennifer Sims , Marketing Systems Manager. Advertising Advisory Committee Meets bi-monthly to review consumer advertising budget allocations, creative concepts and strategies. Reviews special event applications. Advertising Advisory Committee Staff Contact: Kay Galloway Arts, Culture & Heritage Tourism Advisory Committee Meets quarterly to assist staff in reviewing CVB content and to share information with and from the arts and culture community to help ensure that arts and culture is well represented in marketing the destination to visitors. Arts & Culture Advisory Committee Staff Contact: Andrew Booth Biketoberfest® Advisory Committee The Biketoberfest® Advisory Committee meets twice a year and provides assistance in developing the advertising plan and marketing opportunities for this annual event. Members also participate in preparing the Biketoberfest® Master Plan for the City of Daytona Beach. Biketoberfest® Advisory Committee Staff Contact: Kay Galloway Human Resources Advisory Committee Meets quarterly or as needed, providing leadership and support in personnel and human resource areas including employee relations, compensation, benefits and staff development, and assists management with fostering a positive and productive work environment. Human Resources Advisory Committee Staff Contact: Chuck Grimes Meetings & Conventions Advisory Committee Meets quarterly plus potential workshops. Assists the staff in crafting the overall sales plan, to include strategic direction, trade show schedule and other promotions geared toward developing the meetings and conventions business. Meetings & Conventions Advisory Committee Staff Contact: Rashanda Denson Sports Advisory Committee Meets quarterly plus potential workshops and assists in developing strategic direction and marketing opportunities for the development of the group sports market. In addition they assist with the creation of a Local Organizing Committee (LOC) for various sporting events. Sports Advisory Committee Staff Contact: Rashanda Denson Tour & Travel Sales Advisory Committee Meets quarterly plus potential workshops to provide input and overall strategic direction relative to trade show schedules and promotional events. Focuses on developing new opportunities generated by international and domestic tour operators and travel agents. Entertainment Venues Transportation Services Statement of Accessibility ADA Accessibility Feedback Form Partner Gateway Partner Resources Share Public Parking in Daytona Beach With 23 miles of Atlantic shoreline, numerous coastal parks offering convenient parking, and on-beach parking in designated zones, the Daytona Beach area - Ormond Beach, Daytona Beach, Daytona Beach Shores and Ponce Inlet -  has some of the most accessible beaches in Florida. When parking on the beach, parking is available in marked areas just west of the traffic lanes and east of the Conservation Zones. Be sure to park perpendicular to the shoreline, and for safety reasons, please do not position yourself, chairs or umbrellas between cars. Public Parking North of Ponce Inlet There are more than 3,500 public parking spaces at numerous locations adjacent to and near the beaches. Here is a partial list of available places to park, north of Ponce Inlet. Visit Volusia.org for a full-size map of public parking north of Ponce Inlet, that includes these locations: Ormond-by-the Sea Bicentennial , North Shore and Tom Renick parks Ormond Beach Andy Romano Beachfront Park Daytona Beach Sun Splash and Breakers Oceanfront parks Daytona Beach Shores Frank Rendon , Van Avenue and Larry Fornari parks Wilbur-by-the-Sea Heron Street, Toronita Avenue and Major Street Ponce Inlet Winterhaven and Lighthouse Point parks and Inlet Harbor Road Public Parking South of Ponce Inlet Visit Volusia.org for a full-size map of public parking south of Ponce Inlet, that includes these locations: New Smyrna Beach Smyrna Dunes , Flagler Avenue and 27th Avenue parks; and Matthews Avenue South of New Smyrna Beach Bethune Beach Park Questions? While at the beach, feel free to contact one of our friendly Volusia County Beach Patrol officials for assistance. Please contact them at beachsafety@volusia.org and 386-239-7873 or contact us . We're here to help!
